column2: I can generate and use a counterexample to argue that a statement is false.
I can identify limits in indeterminate forms and use appropriate strategies to evaluate the limit.
I can use the limit definition of the derivative to determine the differentiability of a function at a point.
I can use derivatives to solve applied optimization problems.
I can analyze the accumulation function numerically and graphically and compute its derivative.
I can determine input tolerance (delta) from a given function and output tolerance (epsilon).
I can evaluate limits numerically, graphically and algebraically.
I can determine the points at which a function is (and is not) continuous both graphically and algebraically.
I can compute average rates of change and find slopes of secant lines.
I can interpret the meaning of a derivative in context.
I can find the equation of the line tangent to a function at a point and use this line as a linear approximation to estimate the value of a function at nearby points.
I can describe the relationships between f, f' and f'' and use that information to sketch graphs and list intervals of increase/decrease and concavity.
I can compute derivatives for sums, constant multiples, and power, polynomial, trig, exponential, and logarithmic functions using shortcuts.
I can compute derivatives using the product, quotient, and chain rules.
I can compute derivatives using multiple rules in combination.
I can compute derivatives of implicitly defined functions.
I can use calculus and derivative tests to find extreme values and classify them as maxima or minima.
Given a non-constant rate of change, I can estimate the total change over a time interval using a Riemann sum.
I can interpret the meaning of an integral in context and recognize when an integral would be suitable to model a real-life situation.
I can evaluate a definite integral exactly using geometry or the FToC.
I can use shortcuts to compute antiderivatives for sums, constant multiples, and power, polynomial, trig, exponential functions and 1/x.
I can evaluate integrals using the substitution method.
I can use integrals and antiderivatives to solve differential equations and initial value problems.
